Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That matter is not under discussion.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I must be permitted to reply to an interjection.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Interjection s need not be replied to.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: They need not be; but it would be most unjustifiable to permit interjections and to debar the honourable member who is addressing the Committee from replying to them.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I promise the honourable member that there will be no more interjections. If there are, I shall deal with the honourable members who so offend.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: In that case I shall proceed with' my speech. I think that the expenditure proposed in connection with this Department in Queensland should receive the careful scrutiny of honourable members opposite. Several increases are proposed, and the division which is now under consideration-unles s I am mistaken-involve s an expenditure of ;£5 >934-I

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That is quite correct.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That amount is sufficiently large to justify honourable members in rigidly scrutinizing these items in detail. Although the Minister of Home Affairs has accused me of "stone-walling," I have no desire to occupy the time of the Committee.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I can give the honourable member all the information regarding the point to which he refers, in one minute.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I appeal to honourable members opposite to scrutinize these votes a little more carefully, in the interests of the country, so that when they are called upon to appear before their constituents as they may be very soon-the y will be able to justify every vote which they have recorded.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: When you, sir, commenced to put these Estimates in divisions, instead of in subdivisions, I was under the impression that you were adopting a course which had not been assented to by the Committee. It will be recollected that last night, in connection with the Governor General's establishment, you first put subdivision No. 1. I desired to deal with an item in subdivision No. 2, and therefore the Minister of Home Affairs consented to both subdivisions being discussed concurrently. Since then none of the other subdivisions in these Estimates have been put separately.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The Governor General's establishment was the subject of a special concession.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I do not know whether the statement of the Government whip is accurate.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The Government whip has nothing to do with the matter.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I can quite understand that. The way in which honourable membersopposite are prepared to sanction the expenditure of such large sums as are provided for in these divisions, shows that they must have been absolutely satisfied with the administration of the Watson Government, which they were so anxious to " sand-bag " a few months ago.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Thes e are the Estimates of the late Government.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am aware of that. am merely pointing out that they must be eminently satisfactory to honourable members opposite, who were so anxious to displace that Administration.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I understood that the honourable member had risen to a point of order.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: No . I intend to discuss the Queensland Estimates in this Department.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Le t us settle the point of order first.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Ver y well. in view of the practice of putting each division separately, which has previously been adopted by this Committee, a deparfifty-one ture has now been made by putting divi sions separately?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: What has been salary than before. done in the present instance has been frequently done upon other occasions. As matter of fact, if the Committee so desire, the whole of the Estimates may be put as one vote. In matters of this sort, convenience, of honourable members is aldecrease. ways consulted. In the case of the Gover' nor-General's establishment, it is quite I commenced by putting the subdivisions separately. That - practice was found to be inconvenient to honourable members, and for it . accordingly I put the subdivisions together. Honourable members will recollect that the beginning of the Department of Trade and Customs, there are three subdivisions. These were put together, and no objection was raised to the adoption of that course. The leader of the Opposition was present at the time, he heard the division put, and requested that upon it a general discussion should take place. However, I am anxious to consult the desire of honourable members in this matter. Do I understand that they' wish me to put subdivision No. 1HONORABLE MEMBERS - Hear , hear.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I desire to point out the increases for which provision has been made in these items. The Minister of Trade and. Customs stated just now that he could explain the position of these Estimates in one minute, but I have waited for his explanation in vain.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The Minister has not had a chance of explaining.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Will the honourable member permit me to do so now?

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Certainly .

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: In regard to the whole of the Queensland Estimates, there is a decrease of fifty-two in the number ot offiI cers employed for the current vear, as compared with those engaged for 1903-4, and a decrease in the estimate for the present year, as compared with that of last year of £13,046.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am pleased to hear the explanation of the Minister, but if we examine these Estimates carefully, we shall find that many of the officers who have been retained will receive large increases. For instance, the cost of the correspondence branch has been increased from ,£1,027 to £ 1 , 2 2 $ . In the general I ask why, division there has been a slight decrease. subWhile we find that the number of officers in a particular branch has been reduced by or fifty-two, we shall probably discover that they have been transferred to other branches, and are receiving a higher

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: But the cost of the Dea partment in every State has been reduced. Notwithstanding that we have created a new branch for statistics, and also established the the Patents Office, there is an all-round

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That must be very satistrue, factory to the members of the late Government who prepared these Estimates.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I give them every credit

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: As a supporter of the at late Government, I am pleased to hear that, notwithstanding the establishment of these new branches, an all-round decrease has occurred. It is interesting to note that an increase has occurred in the cost of the statistical branch, and that the cost of the clerical division of the analyst's branch is also increasing.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The statistical branch is a new one. Expenditure used to be incut red in respect of it in every separate State, but the work has been consolidated, and on the whole there is a saving.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Accordin g to the Estimates before us, a sum of ^1,678 was expended last year in the maintenance of a statistical branch of the Department in Queensland. That branch must have been in existence, or there would not have been any appropriation °in respect of it. This year there is an increase in the vote for it. I have no desire to " stonewall " the Estimates, although the Minister of Home Affairs suggests that some honourable members have evinced an inclination to do so; but in the interests of the electors who are compelled to pay these increases, I think that we should critically examine them. Many honourable members opposite are apparently quite prepared to agree to any proposed increase, simply because they are sitting behind a Government which has asked them practically to remain dumb, so far as the Estimates are concerned.

Speaker: Mr MCDONA LD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I think that we may fairly ask that progress be reported. We have dealt today with a very important question, involving a large expenditure.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I do not think there is any debatable item remaining to be dealt with in the Estimates of the Department of 'Trade and Customs. Let us pass them before we adjourn. We are not making any creditable progress.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Unde r ordinary circumstances, the question of the policy to be pursued in relation to the sugar industry, which was debated this afternoon, would have been discussed for two or three days. If the question had particularly affected New South Wales, we might have expected the Postmaster-General to deal with it in a speech extending over four or five hours. It is a reasonable time to adjourn. There are many items yet £0 be dealt with in the Estimates of this Department which ought to be discussed.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: If the honourable member desires an explanation as to any item, I shall be pleased to give it.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: On e cannot mention all of them at a moment's notice, but I think it is only reasonable that progress should be reported. . Mr BATCHELOR (Boothby) - I think that the request that progress be reported is a reasonable one. The Government have no right to complain of the progress made by us today.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am not complaining.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: There can be no reason for sitting beyond the hour at which it is usual to adjourn. The discussion of the question affecting the sugar industry certainly did not occupy more time than it was reasonable to expect.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: H as not the honourable member already approved of these Estimates ?

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: No ; I approved of the Estimates of the Department of Home Affairs, but the general .Estimates were not considered by the Cabinet of which I was a member. I have not raised my voice in connection with any item in the Estimates for the Department of Home Affairs, but I had not previously seen the Estimates now before the Committee. Some of the divisions hre of considerable importance. I had intended to make some remarks in regard to the statistical branch of the Department, but the division in which it is provided for, and several other important divisions, were passed hurriedly, while I was absent from the Chamber. The fact that we have had a long discussion on important matters of principle is not a good reason for extending the sitting beyond the usual hour. Mr HU i TCHIS ON (Hindmarsh) - On two or three occasions, when the no-confidence debate was proceeding, I stated that I was willing to sit later if other honourable members would do so, to get on with business, but honourable members opposite then objected that it would be unreasonable to sit after 11 o'clock. We have done good work to-night, and I think it would be wise to adjourn now, so that we may come fresh to the consideration of this division tomorrow.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: If there is any one Department whose Estimates are not contentious it is the Department of Trade and Customs.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Thes e are the most contentious of all the Estimates.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I would be glad to know why? We have a splendid man at the head of the Customs Department, and, although the sub-department of the Patents Office was created towards the end of last year, and a statistical branch has been established, the expenditure of the Department, as a whole, 'has been reduced to the lowest amount compatible with efficiency, so thati the sum asked for is ^13 -526 less than was voted last year. I admit, however, that the establishment of the statistical branch will effect a considerable ing, inasmuch as work which was formerly done in the' States will now be done at the central office. I shall be very glad to give any information desired, but honourable members opposite are as responsible as we are for the progress of business. I am willing to postpone any contentious'proposal, but I think that the rest of the partment should be passed to-night. The leader of the Opposition has, I believe, been through these Estimates, and I am sure that he will admit that there is nothing in them that can reasonably beobjected to.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Personally , I see nothing to object to in the Estimates, though I cannot ask other honourable members to take my word for that. Whoever happens to be in charge of the Estimates must be prepared to meet criticism. The debate to-night has been upon a very important question, and, so far as I know, the time has not been wasted.

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: -It was largely a debate on matters not affected by the Estimates.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: -The first item in a Department is generally used as a peg upon which to hang important criticism, such as that which we have had to-night. I think that we might well adjourn at 11 o'clock. In any case, I do not think we should be asked to go beyond the Queensland division.

Speaker: Mr STORRER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Some honourable members have said that Ministers ought to be satisfied to adjourn now, but the matter may not be of so much consequence to them, because they have to reside in Melbourne to attend to their official duties, as to those who come from the other States. I consider that we should sit either late at night or in the mornings, in order to get through business more quickly. Although the debate, to-night was on an important question of policy, there has been too much repetition. I should like to have sittings on Wednesday and Thursday mornings.

Speaker: Mr MCDONA LD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I protest against the statement of the honourable member for Bass about the debate to-night having been a waste of time.

Speaker: Mr ROBINSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It is quite true.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: No one has wasted more time than has the honourable and learned member. He has frequently stated that that was his object.

Speaker: Mr ROBINSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: /That is incorrect.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I ask the honourable member for Kennedy to discuss the divisavsion before the Committee.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member for Bass was allowed to characterize as a waste of time the discussion of a very important matter, and I desire to reply to him.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member's long parliamentary experience De- must show him that if .that were allowed our proceedings might become interminable. The honourable' member for Bass made a suggestion in connection with the request of the ' leader of the Opposition for an adjournment; but if I allowed the honourable member for Kennedy to discuss it, I should have to extend the same privilege to others. I now ask the honourable member to discuss the question before the Chair.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The position is that other honourable members have already spoken, and that I am denied my right to reply.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I tell the honourable member that he has no right to deal with any matter not under the consideration of the Committee, and I ask him to confine his remarks to the question before us.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: But I want to know why I am singled out in this manner. There is only one. way to have the question discussed. I move That your ruling be disagreed to.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member has written out his motion in the following words, " That your ruling be disagreed with , " but he has not stated what the ruling is. Standing order 228 is as follows:If any objection is taken to a ruling or decision of the Chairman df Committees, such objection shall be stated at once in writing, and may fortlfwith be decided by the Committee; and the proceedings shall then be resumed where they were interrupted. Will the honourable member kindly state in writing the ruling, to which he objects?

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I disagree with your ruling, and it is not necessary for me to do more than to state that.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: What is trie ruling?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member for Kennedy has not seen fit to state what the ruling is.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I rise to order.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Wastin g time !

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: If the " howling dingoes" over there will be still for a moment, I will state my point of order.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Is'the expression "howling dingoes " in order ?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Will the honourable member for Parramatta withdraw that remark. ?

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I withdraw the remark, but I ask to be protected from interruption. ' I say that we have no right to discuss a question which is not stated. There is no question before the Chair, except one which cannot possibly be debated. What is the ruling, and when was it given, itnd in connection with what? The honourable member for Kennedy has submitted a ridiculous motion which cannot possibly be debated.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member for Kennedy has handed me a motion which I put to the Committee, and which, so far as it goes, is in order.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: What is the tuling?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That is for the honourable member for Kennedy to state. If the honourable member desires honourable members to vote in ignorance as to the ruling it is a matter for himself.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The objection I take is that other honourable members were allowed to distinctly accuse honourable members of wasting time, and a charge was levelled against myself Avithout justification. The discussion this afternoon was one of great importance, not only to the House, but to the country.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Will the honourable member confine himself to the question?

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am showing reasons why I object to the ruling-wh y I object to be ruled out of order when I attempt to reply to remarks made by the leader of the Opposition, the Minister in charge of the Estimates, and another honourable member. I have always contended that all honourable members are on the same plane, and none possess privileges over the others.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Do I understand the honourable member to wish to infer that I have been guilty of favouritism, because, if so, I cannot allow the honourable member to continue?

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I hope that the Chairman does not think for a moment that I accuse him of favouritism, but during the discussion certain references were made, and when I attempted to reply I was ruled out of order. The honourable member who accused honourable members of wasting time should have been called to order, but he was not, and his remarks naturally brought forth a reply. I submit the motion because I do not think"! should have been ruled' out of order. However, as I have now really said what I wanted to say, I shall, with the consent of the Committee, withdraw the motion. Motion, by leave, withdrawn.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: We have had a most 1 important discussion this afternoon, which, had we not been hear the end of the session, would, I believe, have occupied a couple of days. Under the circumstances, I think Ave might reasonably adjourn.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am sure that honourable members opposite desire to co-operate with the Government in transacting the public business, whilst Ave, on our Dart, wish to act Will perfect fairness to them. Without asking my honourable friends to do anything at all unreasonable, I think that, in vieAV of our common duties to the public, Ave may fairly pass the Estimates of the Department of Trade and Customs this evening. I haA'e been looking at the Estimates, and I find that all questions of principle and importance haA'e been settled in connection Will the divisions that have been dealt Will.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Oh , no; there is still another important matter to be discussed.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Then let us deal with it, and settle it, instead of postponing it. I do not AA'ish to unfairly tax the endurance of any honourable member, eA'en though he may not be in a very delicate state of health, and I think that my honourable friends opposite will be able to survive the ordeal of a little extra Avork to-night. I do not ask them to go beyond the Department of Trade and Customs. We have not had a really late sitting in connection Will the consideration of the Estimates, and I think that Ave could dispose of the Department IIOAV under consideration before midnight.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: If Ave sit until midnight, . Ave shall sit after it.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Well , sit then.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: -All right, Ave are quite ready for honourable members opposite.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: May I suggest that I am still addressing the Chair, and direct the attention of the honourable member for Coolgardie to the fact that he Avas the first to introduce threatening language.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: When ?

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member did so when he said that if . we sat till midnight, we should sit after it.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The threats came from behind the right honourable gentleman.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Supporter s of the Government have been talking all the evening of sitting until 12 o'clock.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Would that be an appalling thing to ask of strong working men?

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I do not think it should be. We are all workers here, and desire to do a fair amount of business.in the interests of the country. My honourable friends have treated me generously to-night, and I am the man to acknowledge it. But that is a matter quite apart from the question before us. I have a public duty to perform, and I am only asking honourable members to dispose of the Department of Trade and Customs. I admit the value of the discussion that took place this evening. I am raising no complaint upon that point. The subject was a very important one, and some of the information given was very useful. I am entering no complaint, but I would ask the Committee to recognise the period of the session at which we have arrived, and to couclude the consideration of the Department now before the Chair this evening.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I think it is only fair that we should adjourn at this stage. I desire to direct attention to the item in the division under discussion. I think that the Collector at Brisbane receives a very fair salary. Several increases are provided for, and I think that we might test the feeling of the Committee upon these by having a few divisions. I feel disposed to move a slight reduction on the first item. In view of the fact that the Queensland public servants have had to submit to very severe retrenchment, the officers of the Commonwealth employed in that State should be called upon to submit to some reduction. It must be recollected that they do not pay income tax, and that, therefore, they can the better afford to submit to some slight diminution of their salary. The Queensland Commonwealth Customs staff has been reduced by fifty-two officers, and a saving of ;£i 3,000 has been effected. I should like, however, to be satisfied that the efficiency of the Department has been maintained. Although the Collector is a good officer, and performs his work very well, I think that, in view of the necessities of the State, we should require him to submit to some reduction of salary. The interpretation placed by the Treasurer upon the provision in the Constitution with reference to the refunding of three-fourths of the Customs revenue to the various States has inflicted great hardships upon Queensland. I move That the item " Collector, ^ 7 5 0 " be reduced by ^25.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I do hope that individual officers will not be dragged into our little differences here, and made, as a result, to suffer. Personally, I Ho not know the Collector of Customs in Brisbane; but I do know that last year he was voted his present salary by Parliament, and that the collector in Western Australia receives a larger remuneration. Leaving out of consideration the fact that a large quantity of gold is exported from the western State, surely the trade of Queensland warrants us in paying its Collector of Customs a salary equal to that which is paid to a similar officer in Western Australia. I do hope that his salary will not be made the sport of our differences in this Chamber.  honourable member for Kennedy will withdraw his amendment, because the Collector of Customs at Brisbane, Mr Irving, is one of the most capable officers in that Department. He is about 56 or 60 years of age, and may soon be called upon to retire. His salary under the State Government was first j£T5o per year, and the particulars of his service show that he was State Collector of Customs, and was transferred to the service of the Commonwealth on the ist January, 1901, when the Customs Departments of the various States were taken over by the Federal authorities. He has a total service of thirty-six years, and is entitled, on that account, to some consideration.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN

A report which was recently presented to the Minister will give honourable mem-bers an idea of the amount of travelling, by steamer, rail, buggy, and on horseback, which this entails, not only upon his intention spectors, but upon the Collector himself.

I did not hear the honourable member for Kennedy, and, therefore, I am at a loss to understand the reasons which actuated him in moving for a reduction of the item. I have, however, had the advantage of hearing the honourable member for Maranoa, who is a strong advocate of the claims of the Collector. I cannot conceive of any justification for singling out one officer for treatment of the kind proposed by the honourable member for Kennedy. I could have understood his action, if his proposal had formed part of a scheme for a general reduction of the salaries paid to the higher officials of the Commonwealth. Having heard no direct complaint against the officer, I do not feel justified in following the honourable member for Kennedy. When an officer has so many onerous duties to perform in connection with a number of important statutes, his salary should not be reduced unless substantial reasons are advanced. The administration of the law relating to the sugar bounties imposes upon the Collector the most important functions, and the success of that legislation must largely depend upon the discretion which he exercises.  to the state of the Committee. formed.]

We should consider the responsible duties he 1 is called upon to discharge

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member must not be .guilty of repetition.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am not guilty of repetition. If the Chairman had waited for a moment he would have found that I was about to refer to an entirely different matter, namely, the administration of the Immigration Restriction Act.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member is now distinctly out of order in instructing the Chairman as to his duty.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Order ! The honourable member is now contradicting me.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I know that things are getting a little bit mixed', and I can make every allowance for that. We are all becoming a little tired, and perhaps our tempers are being tried to some extent. If a reasonable position had been taken up by the Prime Minister, the present period of irritation might have been avoided. We have had sufficient experience of the administration of the Immigration Restriction Act to know that it requires to be enforced with great care .and discretion, and by officers who will reflect credit upon the framers of the Act, and upon the Government whose servants they are. Inasmuch as no complaint has been lodged against the officer in question, we should pause before we reduce his salary. I believe that when we have a good man we should pay him well. We have heard many complaints that we have not insisted upon the law being strictly administered.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I regret that there is not a quorum present in the Chamber. [Quorum formed.]

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER

Owing to laxity on the part of officials in some of the States of [Quorum the Commonwealth, aliens have been admitted without remonstrance

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I m o v e That the Chairman do now leave the chair. It seems to me, in view of the condition of irritation in which the Committee is, that it would be wise on the part of the Government to agree to adjourn. We have been trying the patience of the Chairman to a great extent to-night, and in his interests, as well as in the interests of the conduct of public business, it is reasonable that we I should now adjourn, and allow the consideration of these Estimates to be resumed tomorrow. I must say that I have never before in this Parliament witnessed anything like what has occurred to-night. Honorable MEMBERS - Hear , hear.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Our honourable friends opposite, including the Minister of Home Affairs, cheer that statement, and yet the Minister is f u l ly aware that only a few months ago, we had in this Chamber some of the most extraordinary exhibitions stone-walling on his behalf, and on behalf of the present Prime Minister.

Speaker: Mr DUGALD THOMSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Neve r during the honourable gentleman's term of office.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Certainl y not. I was anxious to get on with the business, though at the time honourable members in opposition spoke for hours, the standing order which has been put in force to-night was not brought into operation.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: We were fighting for a !big principle.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member for Parramatta was one of those who stonecuss walled for' hours, and yet no attempt was made to put him down. On this occasion, the honourable member for Gwydir was speaking for twenty minutes only, and honmight orable members will admit that he is capable of speaking for more, than twenty minutes without repeating himself.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I rise to a point of order. I submit that it is not in order for the honadjournment orable gentleman to cavil at a decision the Chairman.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN

text: The decision was a decision of the Committee. Mi. REID - I am referring to the Chairman's original direction. Chair, and I hope that no charges will be made against the Chair unless upon some other motion. I submit that we are not at 'refused. present discussing the conduct of the Chair. - Mr WATSON - I think that marks were perfectly in order. I have a complaint to make- I do not say against the Chairman, as such, but against the mittee.

Speaker: An HONOURABLE MEMBER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The Committee supported the Chairman.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I think that the Comwas mittee did wrong, and I think the man did wrong. In my opinion, the mere fact that the Chairman has taken the stand he did, is evidence that he has been too in the Chair on the present occasion, and ing. in his interests, the Committee should journ.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: We can have a deputy-Chairman, and go on with the busisent ness.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It is evident that some(of thing should be done 'when unprecedented action of the kind to which I have referred is taken. The standing order which has been enforced by the Chairman has practically been ignored by every other Chairman we have had. The short space of time and occupied by the honourable member for Gwydir, in my opinion, constitutes a very good argument in support of objections to the course which has been adopted

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member was warned two or three times of his repetitions.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I do not wish to disthat aspect of the matter. It seems to me that there has'been a supersensitiveness apparent to-night, which has not been evident on other" occasions. The Government very well agree to an adjournment at this hour. There was nothing whatever to complain about in the debate during this afternoon, and I think the Government should have been 'prepared to agree to an at II p.m., seeing that no stoneof walling had been indulged in up to that time. Honorable MEMBERS - It had. Mr W'ATSON - I did not notice it.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable gentleman Chairman is was not in the Chamber.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I was not here during of a portion of the evening, nor was the honourable member's leader here at that time.

Speaker: Mr DUGALD THOMSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: An honourable The member was speaking about the length of

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That was long after the request for an adjournment had been

Speaker: Mr DUGALD THOMSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The stonemy rewalling had begun before that.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I can assure the honourable gentleman there would have been no Comrefusal to adjourn if obstruction had not been very apparent before that.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I remind the Minister of Trade and Customs that he said that he not complaining, but desired to finish Chairthe Department under consideration.

Speaker: Mr DUGALD THOMSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It was intimated by honourable members in Opposition long that we might get to a vote tomorrow mornad Mr WATSON - That was after the adjournment had been refused. The Minister of Trade and Customs refused to conto an adjournment at about ten minutes to II o'clock.

Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I appealed to the Committee to pass the Estimates of this Department, but I did not at that stage refuse the adjournment.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I do not say that there was a technical refusal to adjourn, but at about twelve or ten minutes to 11 o'clock the honourable gentleman said that he had no reason to complain of what had happened up to that time, but he thought the Committee might very well pass the remaining portion of the Estimates of the Customs Department. I said that I had no objection to that being done, although I could not speak for other honourable members who might desire to discuss the Estimates. I mentioned that I would do what I could to get the Queensland portion of the Estimates through. I may mention that I have just been informed that four members on the Government side spoke on the Estimates between 7.30 p.m. and the request for the adjournment at about 1:0.45 P- - So far as I heard the debate during the afternoon, it was on an important matter of administration, and the time occupied could not be considered as wasted. The business of the House would have been facilitated by an adjournment at or about 11 o'clock. Honourable members have since naturally become somewhat irritated, and there has not been the progress we have a right to expect. I feel that if we are io get the business of the session done, especially in view of the Standing Orders in force in this House, it can only be by extending consideration to every member of the House.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That is precisely what honourable members opposite have declared they will not do.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I have not noticed any absence of consideration on their, part. If there had been any desire on their part to display a lack' of consideration, it could have been shown this evening. The honourable member for Parramatta ought to know that his chief and other honourable members could not have fulfilled their engagements' this evening if honourable members on this side had decided to harass the Government.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: -What has that to do with it ?

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It shows that there has been no desire on the part 'of honourable members on this side to harass the Government, and it also shows the unfairness of the honourable member for Pairamatta in continually charging Us with obstruction when, as a matter of fact, we have shown ' 11 A 2 reasonable consideration for the members of the Government. The conduct of public business would be served by an adjournment now. It does not strike me as a very likely way of insuring the rapid despatch of business that honourable members should be irritated as they have been to-night. With the utmost desire to have our business disposed of in a reasonable time, I strongly urge that we should be allowed to go home now, that we may take up our work tomorrow in a better frame of mind.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I should like the leader of the Opposition to recall a slightly more accurate view of the situation than he has expressed. I suppose the proposition will not be questioned that, no matter what Government is in power, it is in a special degree responsible" for the conduct of public business. When I suggested to the Committee that we should finish the Estimates of this Department, as there was no important m matter connected with them to be decided, the request was made that we should adjourn at 11 o'clock. I did not see my way to comply with that request, in view of the state of public business, the state of the Estimates, and the desire that we should finish this Department. Matters of principle connected with the latter portion of these Estimates have been debated in dealing with other votes, and yet, when I made my statement, the remark was made, " We l l, we will sit after midnight."

Speaker: Mr DAVID THOMSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That remark came from the Government side.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I think it was provoked by the honourable member for Corangamite.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I do not apprehend that the honourable member for Corangamite is anxious to throw difficulties in my way. The Opposition, as represented by the honourable member for Coolgardie, immediately indulged in a threat.

Speaker: Mr MAPION
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: In response to threats made by honourable members sitting behind the Government.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It was impossible for me to accept dictation from honourable members of the Opposition. I will go further. The conduct of certain honourable members since 11 o'clock in connection with an amendment moved by the honourable member for Kennedy, has been an intimation to the Committee which a child could interpret, of the deliberate intention-no t of the Opposition, but of two or three irresponsible members of it-to prevent the transaction of public business, and to take the conduct of affairs out of the hands of the Government. A Government which would submit to that should not exist for a single day. The conduct of three honourable members has been an open, unashamed obstruction of public business.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I rise to order.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I withdraw the expression, to save time. The manner in which the honourable member for Kennedy spoke in support of his amendment, and the ludicrous details as to the personal appearance of the officer affected, such as whether he wore a beard or not, his height, baptism, and birth, discussed by the honourable member for Maranoa, were evidence of anintention to waste time, of which a child could see the significance. Then the honourable member for Gwydir, under the plea of opposing the amendment, joined the other two in their common, design-no t lo discuss the item, by objecting to the officeror the salary allotted to him,. which has been voted over and over again-bu t for a reason which those who have the progress of business at heart cannot appreciate-to hinder the consideration of the Estimates. I am not here to help those who wish to block public business, though I shall not lose my temper if other honourable members take a different view of their responsibilities. My usefulness as leader of the House would be absolutely gone if I allowed an honourable member, by means of a threat, to alter the mind of the Committee. Is it not strange that vigorous men, who have lived lives of healthy toil, should talk of being exhausted at 11 o'clock at night? Those members of the Committee who have been reared in the lap of luxury might complain of feeling languid, but surely members of the Labour Party, who possess a magnificent physique, sarned by honest work, some of them in mines, hewing out the solid metal, hundreds of feet below the surface, cannot make that excuse, after the example of heroic activity which they have shown in travelling from one end of the Continent to another to attend public meetings. The people expect us to do our duty in regard to these Estimates. If honourable gentlemen insist on moving amendments for the sole purpose of blocking business, which they mayconsider a good purpose, I hope that other honourable members will listen to them in good temper; but, surely, the Chairman must have the sympathy of even' honourable member in the fearless and honest performance of his duty, without regard to party. If we each judged of his decisions as they affected us personally, it would be useless to have a Chairman.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: If party interests are to be considered, my rights are gone.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member is in a state of compressed excitement, which is dangerous; but he, like all of us, must obey the Chair.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am ready to submit to a just judgment.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member is not to be the judge in his own cause. The Chairman has decided that his conduct came within the meaning of the standing order, and it is the duty of every honourable member to support the ruling of the Chair.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Righ t or wrong?

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Thos e who heard the honourable member for Gwydir, know that the decision of the Chairman was one which he was absolutely called upon to pronounce.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That is bound to be said by those on the Government side of the Chamber.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member's manner was that of a condemned criminal. He was not speaking on the merits of the question in the magnificent way to which we are accustomed. There has been a design to waste time, to which - the Government cannot be a party. If the leader of the Opposition asks us to adjourn now, without doing any business, he invites us to allow the Committee to be fooled every night, at' the whim of two or three irresponsible members of his party, and I shall not agree to that. I do not care what task is placed upon our physical endurance, the moment the signal of defiance is run up, and an attempt is made to take the transaction of public business out of the hands of the Government, we are compelled to assume an attitude of resistance. I hope, however, that the Labour Party will not falsify the handsome compliments which I paid them before they had tasted blood, and got entangled in the meshes of office. They are raoidlyimitating the most degenerate politics of Australia. What has become of their high regard for the public interest, and their disregard for the loaves and fishes of office? I hope that they will allow the Estimates for this Department to be passed. The Government have no desire to go further tonight; but we must pass these Estimates if it takes a week to do so. be a trial of brute strength, the sooner it takes place the better.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I regret 4ha.t it should have fallen to my lot to move that your ruling be dissented from, Mr Chairman; but I cannot allow it io pass unchallenged. I feel that' a very iseiious error was made by you, and, without wasting time, or making use of a word that would give the slightest offence either to you or to any honourable gentleman opposite, I respectfully submit that your decision cannot be upheld by the Committee. Directly you had informed the Committee - that the honourable member for Gwydir was guilty of tedious repetition understanding order 276, I rose to move that your ruling be dissented from, and you then told the Committee that what you had given was a decision, not a ruling. Standing order 276 ceads as follows: The Speaker or the Chairman of Committees may call the attention of the House or the Committee, as the case may be, to continued irrelevance or tedious repetition, or the taking up of time by a - speech of such unwarrantable length as to obstruct the business on the part of a member, and may - direct such member to discontinue his speech-. You ruled that your direction under that standing order is not a ruling which may be challenged by the Committee. I respectf u l l y submit that it is, and in support of my position I refer you to standing order 228, which say'sI f any objection is taken to a.ruling or decision of the Chairman of Committees, such objection .shall be stated at once "in writing, and may forthwith be decided by the Committee; and the proceedings shall then be resumed where they were interrupted. I am aware that dissent from the ruling of the Chairman must be made directly that ruling is given, and, therefore, I took the earliest opportunity to raise the question.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: My direction to the honourable member for Gwydir was neither a Tuling nor a decision.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It must have been one or the other.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: There was nothing to decide; there was no question before the Chair. The Standing Orders provide for action on my part under such circumstances, without it being possible to raise a point of - order, or to challenge my ruling.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: This is the first time that such a ruling has been given in this Parliament.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I hope that it will be the last. If there is to The CHAIRMAN - I warned the honourable member for Gwydir several times.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It is with great regret that I dissent from your ruling that your direction is unchallengeable. You declared that the honourable member for Gwydir had been guilty of continued irrelevance or tedious repetition within the meaning of standing order 276, and you directed him not to continue his speech, so that you actually gave two decisions. I feel considerably hurt, therefore, that you should, in defiance of the Standing Orders, refuse to receive my motion of dissent, and I takethis opportunity, in no spirit of ill-feeling, to protest against your decision. I hope that the eariiest opportunity will be taken to obtain the opinion of the Speaker on the question. Every honourable member who has heard your ruling has been greatly astonished by it, and especially by your action in refusing to accept a motion of dissent upon it. If your ruling be correct, you and an accidental majority of one could dominate proceedings in Committee, and prevent honourable members on this side of the Chamber from being heard.

Speaker: Mr DUGALD THOMSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: So could the Speaker and an accidental majority of one dominate proceedings in the House.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: If the ruling is a good one, the Speaker would be in the same position. I do not think that the ruling is sound. To jme it appears pdntrary to common-sense and destructive of the traditional right of members of a British Parliament to the exercise of the utmost liberty of speech.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Of course, the Government must decide how the business of Parliament is to be carried on; but the Prime Minister's experience of all-night sittings in the New South Wales Parliament must have led him to form the opinion that they do not conduce to the forwarding of business, and are not likely bo maintain the best traditions of parliamentary government. A number of important speeches have been made in regard to matters relating to the administration of the Department, the consideration of whose Estimates was commenced this afternoon. This debate was participated in by both sides of the House.

Speaker: Mr DUGALD THOMSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Tw o hours were occupied by one side, and five hours by the other.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I scarcely know what the Minister means. If he means that one side properly discussed the matter, and the other side obstructed,, there might be some point in his remark. If , however, it is admitted that it was fair discussion, If a to see the point. I took no par?, because the matter on which I wished to say a word was on another item connected with New South Wales, and I wished to reserve my remarks for that item. I had occasion to leave the Chamber for a few minutes, and when I returned I found that the whole of the votes of this division had been' disposed of.  the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: On my return I found that, owing to the method first adopted having been departed from, several divisions of the Department had been passed without the consideration of the principal States. The votes connected with the Central Staff, the Patent Office, and the Statistician's Department-the two latter being new branches created during the year, and having jurisdiction in very important matters, which might have occasioned some debate-ha d been dealt with, and the Committee were engaged in considering business connected with the State of Queensland. In that short space of time, there had been authorized an expenditure of over ,£200,000 out of a total of ,£269,000. From the money stand-point, which is a big standpoint as affecting the electors, we had done a considerable amount of work before the adjournment was asked for. I must disclaim any charge of obstruction on my part. It is true that on, those, as on previous Estimates, I have had a word to say, but on those occasions my words have been brief and to the point. I have all along been voting with the Government until tonight, when the motion was for the purpose of gagging a member. I have taken part in another place in a number of divisions on a similar question; but I have always opposed applying the gag; and, until I see gpod reason, I shall not alter my attitude. I do not think the motion to which I now refer was warranted to-night. If , however, it is to be applied, as in the case of the honourable member for Gwydir, it is possible that in time, the whole of the Opposition may be gagged, and the Government permitted to carry their measures by brute force. I am prepared to give the Government every help in the expedition of business, when I am in reasonable agreement with their proposals; and I think I have shown that that is my desire.

Speaker: Mr DUGALD THOMSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Does the honourable member believe in time being occui l pied in describing the personal appearance of public officers?

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Whil e I do not believe in that course, I think that when the Government refused the adjournment, they invited some action of the kind. I am now speaking for myself only. If we are to have a repetition of what we saw to-night, when threats were hurled from one side of the Committee to the other, we may well be afraid, seeing that an honourable member's mouth has been shut, that measures may be carried by brute force.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: We have had precious little of that, I am sure.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I hope we shall have no more.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It is no pleasure to me.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Did the honourable member for Canobolas hear an honourable member of the Opposition say that the Government would be given a taste of what the Opposition could do ?

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I heard an honourable member on the other side say that the Opposition would be given a taste of what the Government could do.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: And I should think the Government would respond !

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The trouble was started on the Government side. M i . LONSDALE - It did not.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I heard a challenge from tht Government side, before I heard one from the Opposition side. What we desire is to carry on the business in a reasonable way; and the present spirit is not that in which to conduct the government of the country. If we are to have these, all-night sittings

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Who is making it an all night sitting?

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I think the Prime Minister cannot charge me with obstructing business.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member is doing a little bit now.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I ask the Prime Minister now, whether he cannot see his way clear to grant an adjournment? Personally, I am quite prepared to meet tomorrow mOrning at 10 o'clock, in order to carry on the business.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member knows that when the Opposition takes charge, it is time for the Government to show fight.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: If the Government want to show fight

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The Government have to do so, if they have any manliness.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I think that when the Opposition asked for an adjournment, there was no reason for the attitude assumed by the Government.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Was it not in reason to ask honourable members to sit a little later than 11 o'clock?

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That is a matter of opinion. If the Government have drawn their sword, that is another matter, and it is useless to appeal for other methods.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Parramatta) Honourable members opposite are most unreasonable in their attitude. The leader of the Opposition has time and again invited the House to sit all night, and I was one who protested against his request a. little while ago.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: On what question was that ?

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I cannot recall the question.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I say that that never sire to interfere. took place.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That settles the matter, I suppose. One begins to understand the intelligence at the back of this obstruction. I am surprised at the honourable member for Canobolas, who is usually a fair man in this Chamber. could understand "stone-walling" on a big principle, such as the imposition of a new Tariff.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Then I suppose the honourable member would be justified in " stonewalling " ?

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Any honourable member is justified in " stone-walling" a measure, if he thinks such course in the public interest. a well recognised rule in a parliamentary sense; but are honourable members opposite following that rule now?

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Yes .

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Then one memvoured ber, at any rate, says that the Estimates should be obstructed.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: That is unfair.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The Estimates are the only question before the Housean officer's salary.

Speaker: Mr WATKINS
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: What the honourable member for Gwydir said was that he was doing what the honourable member for Parregret ramatta spoke of as correct.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I have yet to learn that there is any sense in the drivelling inanities which are going on from night to night in connection with the Estimates. I appeal to honourable members to be reasonable, ancl allow the Estimates to go through, so as to enable us to get into recess.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Is the Government procedure going to attain that end?

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am not complaining of the time that was occupied on an important subject this afternoon. But it is a different matter when an honourable member moves an obstructive motion, and is followed by another honourable member who declares that he will give the Government a taste of what the Opposition can do.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The sum of ,£200,000 had been voted before that occurred.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: There , is no reason why the whole should not have been passed, seeing that there are no debatable items in the Estimates of the Department, That is proved by the item which has been picked out for discussion-the salary of an officer with whose salary there is no deI f this had been a legitimate proposal, I could have understood it, but an honourable member first submits a motion, and then asks another honourable member to oppose it.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I never did.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable I member invited the honourable member for Maranoa to oppose the proposal.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member is quite wrong.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: And the honourable member for Maranoa 'opposed the motion in a most obedient and docile way. It is patent that the present proceeding is for one purpose only, namely, to oba struct the passage of the Estimates, and That is thereby prevent the payment of the public servants.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The .'honourable member for. Canobolas, and another honourable member have, in my opinion, endeato place the responsibility for my action on the Government. I wish honourable members to understand that I accept fully and completely all responsibility. I am in a position in which I have a duty to perform; and it was only after careful consideration, without consulting anyone, and after warning the honourable member for Gwydir twice, that I took action. I very much that I was compelled to interfere; and after warning the honourable member twice, I would take the same course again under similar circumstances. I do not wish any one to be blamed for an action which I took on my own responsibility.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The course of events during the last hour is in my opinion unparalleled in the history of British Parliaments. I do not think that in any British Parliament any such power is relegated to the Chairman of Committees as that which has been exercised to-night.

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: What are the Standing Orders for?

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The Standing Orders are absolutely out of accord with precedent if they are interpreted rightly by the Chairman.' Standing Orders which govern debate in Committee, whether in New South Wales, or any other State, contain a provision under which an honourable member may be called upon to desist from speaking if , in the opinion of the Committee, by a certain specified, and not by a simple majority, he has transgressed. Yet, in the Parliament qf the Commonwealth, should we happen to have a partisan Chairman, backed up by a party with a solid majority, it would be possible for any honourable member against whom that Chairman had a strong feeling, to be called upon to cease speaking under any circumstances. When I was called to order. I had been speaking for twenty minutes only upon a most important subject.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It was not a matter of time, as the honourable member must know.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I did not know it .

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I told the honourable member so.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: --Even so. I maintain even now that I had no intention of obstructing the business of the Committee or of repeating myself.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: How . can honourable member say that?

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I cannot, in a matter of this kind, submit to the judgment of honourable members opposite. The honourable member for Parramatta has referred to obstruction and " stone-walling," and a number of other things, but he admitted at a former stage that the discussion which took place upon the question of the sugar bounties was of a perfectly legitimate character.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I had no objection to that.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The Prime Minister has nothing to complain about with regard to the manner in which the business has been conducted up to the present time. I cannot be justly accused of having delayed the progress of business, or of having in dulged in unnecessary repetition. I spoke for only twenty minutes upon a perfectly legitimate motion, when I was called upon by the Chairman to cease speaking, on the ground that I was guilty of tedious repetition and continued irrelevance. The Standing Orders do not warrant the Chairman in assuming the character of a dictator, and I certainly shall not submit to humiliation at his hands. If his dictum is to be accepted, he could, with the assistance of a gagging majority, practically close the mouths of every member of the minority.  to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: To-da y I addressed myself quite legitimately to the subject which was then under discussion. To-night, also, I took up a certain attitude, because I entertained the opinion that an unfair proposal had been made to reduce the salary of a Customs official.

Speaker: Sir JOHN FORREST
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Rubbis h !

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I can scarcely credit that the right honourable member for Swan is so ungenerous as to refuse to accept my assurance.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The honourable member knows nothing whatever about this particular officer.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: Surely it is not necessary that I should be personally acquainted with every officer in the Public Service before I am at liberty to stand up and defend him. I had been speaking only twenty minutes when I was adjudged guilty of tedious repetition. the Mr JOHNSON - The honourable member has already said that a dozen times.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I do not intend to be dictated to by the honourable member for Lang. He seems to be rapidly developing into a dictator-general. I again ask the Prime Minister to agree to an adjournment! of the debate.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I have been anxious to adjourn it for a long time. Let us first put' through two or three pages of the Estimates.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am not responsible for the delay which has occurred. The Chairman alone is responsible. Will the Prime Minister agree to an adjournment ofi the debate upon the Estimates when we have disposed of those relating to Queensthat land?

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: The whole of the Estimates of the six States have been framed upon tion. the same basis. We have passed those lating to three States without any objection being offered. Why not dispose of the 'criticism, other three?

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: It is now 2 o'clock way. in the morning, and if the Prime Minister remains obdurate, what will be the result?

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: If I agreed to the suggesfallacies. tion of the honourable member we should pass the Queensland Estimates in two minutes, and it would only occupy four more minutes to pass those relating to the other two States.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I cannot admit that. No good can be accomplished by initiating all-night sittings. They are calculated demoralize the Parliament, to undermine the health of honourable members, and to induce them to say things which do. redound to their credit.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I will help the honourable member along if he will only little bit.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADVANTAGE TO FOREIGN
text: I am perfectly preEstimates. pared to trust the Prime Minister. I regret that I have been the cause of an incorrect decision on the part of the Chairman, or of something worse than that.

Speaker: The ACTING
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: Is the honourable member reflecting upon the Chair?

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: No ; I am speaking of the Chairman who is now absent. These all-night sittings, I contend, are calculated .to make - honourable members unreasonable towards one another. Personally, I believe that the'Chairman was growing tired; that he was suffering from mental exhaustion, and that consequently he was induced rule as he did. I think that he was cerely desirous of doing his best dite the conduct of public business.

Speaker: The ACTING
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: I think that the honourable member is reflecting upon the Chair.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: Thes e all-night sitthe tings are productive of no good results. future,. I trust that the Prime Minister allow the Committee to adjourn sonable hour.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: Coolgardie) beard a good deal of specious reasoning as - to why the Committee should conclude consideration of the Estimates relating Customs Department before progress is ported. The Prime Minister has declared there is no principle involved in them, inasmuch as the Estimates of two States were passed without any opposi- ' I would point out that if the reCommittee made a mistake in allowing those Estimates' to pass without we shall be duplicating that mistake if we agree to the balance in the same I am surprised that so keen a logician as the Prime Minister should have attempted to mislead the Committee by such Certainly, I could never subscribe to such a doctrine. As I remarked upon a previous occasion, the silence of honourable members opposite is extremely significant. I entertain a great regard for them, and I trust that I shall see them in another Parliament. However much honourable members desire to dodge a disto solution they will be compelled to face one very soon. It is just as well that they should recognise the dangers which confront not them. The other day I was fortunate enough to discover that an Italian nobleman had been entertained by the Ministry at trust me a the public expense.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: That item is not upon these

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: I would remind the Prime Minister that we are now discussing the motion that the Chairman shall leave the Chair. When we resume the consider a(Mr. tion of the Estimates, I shall have a good' deal to say upon the various items; but I now make another appeal to the Government to adjourn. We know that it is magnificent to have a giant's strength, but it is tyrannous to use it as a giant; and the Prime Minister, having a majority to-night, should be magnanimous.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: If we consent to adjourn to now, will the honourable member promise to sinput the rest of the Estimates-in-Chief to expethrough at the next sitting?

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: All but the Post Office (Mr estimates.

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: I promise that, so far as I am concerned, I shall not object to whole of the Customs and Treasury esI n timates going through at the next sitting. will If that is done, I think we shall have made at a reavery good progress.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: Can the honourable mem-We have ber speak for his partu?

Speaker: Mr MAHON
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: No . I only speak for the myself. We* differ only in our methods of to the arriving at the same Tesult.. and at this rehour, with the greatest confidence in the magnanimity of the Government, I make another appeal to the Prime Minister to adjourn.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: I hope that as we have sat so late, the Prime Minister will stand firm in the position which has been forced upon him, and will insist on passing the estimates of the Customs Department before we adjourn.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: I desire to point out that the Prime Minister was wrong in supposing that after we have dealt with the estimates for the Queensland branch,, there is nothing to be discussed in connection with the rest of the estimates of the Customs Department.' If the right honourable gentleman will look at page 56 of the Estimates, he will find an entirely new item, " To adjust salaries of officers entitled to increments under State laws, £ 2 3 7 . " opens up a very big question, and a matter of very great importance to the whole of the South Australian officers in the Commonwealth Service. Under the classification scheme, the salaries of South Australian officers have been reduced in a far greater degree than those of officers in any of the other States. This is recognised to some extent by the Government, but a very much greater sum than is provided for on these estimates will be required if the promise of the Public Service Commissioner - that no officer is to have his salary reduced in consequence of the classification, is to be given effect to. There will necessarily be a good deal of. debate on the item to which I have referred, and I remind honourable members that the matter has been before the House now for a very long time.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: Then it is about time it was settled.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: The right honourable gentleman should know that it could not be dealt with until we came to the item on the Estimates. I might have referred to the question on the first line of these estimates; but I felt that it would be more fair to discuss the matter when we reached this vote. I have referred to the question now in order to show that the Prime Minister was mistaken in .supposing that the consideration of the estimates for the Queensland branch of the Customs Department should satisfy honourable members.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: It might be possible journ the consideration of the debatable items to which the honourable gentleman refers.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: That would overcome the immediate difficulty, but we should not know when an opportunity would be given to deal with the question.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: I would guarantee that an opportunity would be given.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: All that I am concerned about in this connection is that the fullest opportunity should be given to discuss that particular item in the South Australian Customs estimates, and certainly the proper thing to do is to discuss it when we come to it in the ordinary course.

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: The request for an adjournment was made at a leasonable hour, and the action of the Government in refusing to grant it has not brought about very satisfactory results, a state of irritation having been created which has caused a display of ill-temper on both That sides of the Chamber, and a new rule as to the conduct of debate has been made, which are both to be regretted. I have stayed here against my personal inclination - becaus e I am opposed to all-night sittings - in order to bring before the Committee the manner in which the Immigration Restriction Act has been administered in Western Australia.

Speaker: Mr WATKINS
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: Hear , hear. I have a word to sav on that subject, too.

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: Wester n Australia is being flooded with foreigners of all descriptions, who are coming into the country under the very eyes of the Customs officials. I think, however, that it is too late to discuss the matter now. Surely, as business men, we can come to some reasonable compromise which will enable us to get to bed, and will bring us here fresh for tomorrow's sitting. I appeal to the Prime Minister to make a suggestion for such, a compromise.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: CHAIRMAN
text: I pointed out last night that a few weeks ago, when honourable members on this side of the Chamber were anxious to sit late to finish the no-confidence debate, Ministerial supporters objected, and yet they opposed the adjournment to-night. The Committee was in a good frame of mind when the adjournment was suggested at 11 o'clock, and I am sure that even the Prime Minister will admit that nothing has been gained by not consenting to adjourn. In my opinion, nothing will be gained by continuing the present proceedings. The Chairman to adwas good enough to allow me to proceed perhaps further tlian was quite" in conformity with the rules of debate, in'introducing the matter which has been referred to by the honourable member for Boothby. It was then pointed out to me that a proper occasion for its discussion would arrive later. It is not, however, fair to ask us to discuss it at this hour, when many honourable members are away. I wish also to say something in regard to the administration of the Customs Department in South Australia.

Title: CHAIRMAN
text: Parramatta) Although the honourable member for Hindmarsh says that rhe Committee was in a good frame of mind at 11 o'clock, today's Age-surel y an impartial judge-say s of our proceedings last nightAfter a general talk about the White Australia question, sugar bonuses, the advisability of authorizing the Tariff Commission to inquire into the sugar industry
